xxl.core.pipes.processors
Class HazardDelayManager

java.lang.Object
  xxl.core.cursors.AbstractCursor<Long>
      xxl.core.pipes.processors.HazardDelayManager
All Implemented Interfaces:
Iterator<Long>, Cursor<Long>
public class HazardDelayManager
extends AbstractCursor<Long>

Generates a delay manager for a Processor based on a hazard rate function. A hazard rate function determines the event probability, i.e., events per second.

Since:
1.1

Constructor Detail

HazardDelayManager

public HazardDelayManager(RealFunction function,
                          double interval,
                          double offset)
Create a DelayManager with this hazard function. The algorithm will discretize the function in steps of the length 'interval' and will start at the point 'offset'.

Parameters:
function - hazard function
interval - discrete interval in ms
offset - offset of the function
Method Detail

public static RealFunction getPeriodFunction(RealFunction origin,
                                             double minValue,
                                             double periodLength)
Creates a Function, which repeats the origin function on the interval [0;period).

Parameters:
origin - The origin Function with one period.
periodLength - The period length
Returns:
function which repeat the origin function on [0;period)

getPeriodSplineFunction

public static RealFunction getPeriodSplineFunction(double[] gridPoints,
                                                   double[] delayValues)
Get a spline interpolated hazard function with delays for the given grid points.

Parameters:
gridPoints - timepoints for given delays in milliseconds
delayValues - delay times in milliseconds
Returns:
Interpolated hazard function

nextObject

public Long nextObject()
Description copied from class: AbstractCursor
Returns the next element in the iteration. This element will be accessible by some of the cursor's methods, e.g., update or remove, until a call to next or peek occurs. This is calling next or peek proceeds the iteration and therefore its previous element will not be accessible any more.

This abstract operation should implement the core functionality of the next method which secures that the cursor is in a proper state when this method is called. Due to this the nextObject method need not to deal with exception handling.

Specified by:
nextObject in class AbstractCursor<Long>
Returns:
the next element in the iteration.

public static void main(String[] args)
